Luca, I'm not sure if I understand your question.  The substrate in 
HyperN=
EAT is the geometric space of the neural network.  In other 
words, nodes a=
re situated at location in the subtrate.  HyperNEAT then 
decides how to co=
nnect those nodes by querying a CPPN to ask for the 
connection weights.

S=
o you could say that it "substitutes" for the "random generation of 
connec=
tions," but that is not really accurate because the CPPN still 
receives ra=
ndom connections from mutations in the same way the the 
neural network doe=
s in regular NEAT.

The difference is that in HyperNEAT, the CPPN (which is=
 the genome) 
actually generates the neural network, whereas in regular NEA=
T the 
genome and the neural network are the same thing (which is it is 
ca=
lled a "direct encoding")

I also do not know what you mean by "use a subst=
rate as an activation 
function."  A substrate is an entire network, which =
may perform a 
highly complex task.  It may have multiple outputs.  So I am=
 not sure 
if it makes sense to use it as a single activation function, unl=
ess it 
is part of some kind of larger hierarchical structure, but I am not=
 
sure if that would be very useful.

ken
